From Charlottesville, head west on I-64 towards Staunton.  Head south on I-81 until you reach Raphine, VA and get off onto route 606 heading east towards Vesuvius.  Head south on route 56 and then continue on to route 608 heading south until you reach South Big Mary’s Creek, where a camp site is located.  Site 703 is located up the first jeep trail just over 1/2 of a mile from the camp road.

properties.Directions: From Charlottesville, VA head west on I-64 towards Staunton.  Take the VA-624 exit – EXIT 96 toward Waynesboro/Lyndhurst.  Turn left on Mount Torry Road, then a right onto Coal Road.  From Coal Road, turn left onto Mills Creek Trail and follow the trail until you reach a large dam where the lake is located.

Follow the Coal Road out of Stuarts Draft and through GW National Forest.  Easily about 10 miles on the Old Coal Road, you will encounter a long straightaway and cross two intermenient streaems.  If you encounter the Tramway, go back about 1/2 mile.
From 29 S turn R on VA 683.  Pull off the road next to the 683-691 intersection.  The site is on the left side of 683, where an old dirt road has been fenced off.
from 29S, turn L onto 738S.  Turn L onto VA 677 toward the N.  Turn R on the 3rd road to the right.  follow road to top of the hill and the gate.  site is on the left

From US 81, take state road 263 west for about 4 miles, to state road 716.  Take 716 north for about 3.5 miles to 711.  Take 711 east for about 1/3 mile, there will be a driveway on the right and a house visible from the road.  The site is about 500 feet behind the house, heading slightly uphill.
Take US 460 west to state road 659.  Take 659 southwest for about 1/3 mile to a private drive.  Take the private road 0.2 miles south, and then enter the woods to the east for about 200 feet.

From US 460, about 5 miles west of the intersection with state road 24, there should be a private road  on the left (heading south).  Take this road about 1 mile ultil it forks, follow the left fork for 1/3 mile.  There should be an intersection of two private roads, the site is 75 feet on the left (east) in the woods.

From Columbia Furnace take route 675 west.  Take left fork onto route 717.  After 2 miles turn left onto route 690.  Travel 1.5 miles to stream crossing.  After stream crossing turn left onto forest service road.  Travel 1/4 mile down the forest service road and park.  Sites are on the top of 3 mile mountain which is on the left.  Climb up anywhere and locate the trail on the northwest side of the ridge.  Site is located 250 yards south of rock outcrop along the trail..

Take I81 north towards Broadway.  Merge onto US259 then onto US42 north.  Come to the railroad tracks at Timberville and follow the tracks about 500 ft to the left.

properties.OlacNotes:
THE MINE SITE IS LOCATED WITHIN 100' OF STATE ROUTE 605.  WHILE NO SITE VISITATION WAS NOTED, THE AREA POSES A SLIGHT HAZARD TO THE PUBLIC DUE TO SEVEN  CAVED SHAFTS EXISTING ON THE SITE.  THE LARGEST SHAFT IS 25 X 25 X 10' DEEP WITH THE OTHER BEING 8 X 8 X 5' DEEP.  THE SHAFTS ARE DRY WITH DUMP MATERIAL LOCATED ON THE RIMS.

NO PROCESSING WAS NOTED AND THE ACIDIC DRAINAGE WHICH OCCURS OFF SITE (5.5 PH) IS MOST LIKELY DUE TO ACIDIC SOILS.

properties.Directions: FROM RT. 60 IN AMHERST COUNTY, TRAVEL RT. 600 SOUTH TO RT 622 FOR APPROXIMATELY 1 MILE.  MINE SHAFTS ARE ON RIDGE BEFORE YOU REACH THE JUNK YARD.
properties.OlacNotes:
OLP-02-01, HAZARDS ELIMINATED= 5 PITS, 4 SHAFTS, 200+ TIRES AND TRASH, 2 ACRES SEEDING. 

A 50' VERTICAL SHAFT AND SEVEN INCIDENCES OF SUBSIDENCE EXIST ON THE SITE.  A HAZARD TO THE PUBLICS SAFETY IS PRESENT AT THE SHAFT IS WITHIN 20' OF ST. RT. 622 AND 100' OF A HOME.  NO ENVIRONMENTAL HARM WAS NOTED WITH THE EXCEPTION OF THE HOLES BEING UTILIZED AS AN ILLEGAL DUMP FOR DEFECTIVE TIRES.

THE SITE IS A WATERFILLED QUARRY. HIGHWALLS ARE PRESENT.  THE SITE IS BLOCKED OFF AT THE ROAD WITH LARGE BOULDERS AND IS NOT READILY ACCESSIBLE.  LITTLE SITE VISITATION WAS NOTED.  THERE NOT A FENCE AROUND THE MAJORITY OF THE QUARRY.  ENVIRONMENTAL HAZARDS ARE DEEMED SLIGHT.  SAFETY HAZARDS ARE DEEMED MODERATE DUE TO THE FACT THAT THE HIGHWALLS ARE NOT FENCED.  EVALUATION SUMMARY SCORES WERE ENVIRONMENTAL: 15
SAFETY: 12
EXPOSURE: 14

properties.Directions: ALONG KNIGHTS BRANCH OFF THE SOUTH SIDE OF A WOODS ROAD ABOUT 1.1 MILES BY ROAD SW OF ITS INTERSECTION WITH STATE ROUTE 606 AT MASTINS CORNER.  APPROXIMATELY 1.4 MILES SE OF PORTERS, VA.
properties.OlacNotes:
GIVEN AN 'A' RATING FIRST (11/30/1988): SEVERE ENVIRONMENTAL DEGRADATION DUE TO ACID MINE DRAINAGE. POSSIBILITY OF SHAFTS PRESENT WHICH POSE A HAZARD TO THE PUBLIC SAFETY.  MORE RESEARCH NECESSARY ON SHAFT LOCATIONS PRIOR TO RECLAMATION ATTEMPTS

RECLASSIFIED:A REQUEST FOR NEW CLASSIFICATION IS MADE DUE TO THE FACT THAT EXTREMELY ACIDIC DRAINAGE IS PRESENT AND UNTIL EPA STORMWATER REGULATIONS ARE FINALIZED AND LIABILITY FOR THESE SITE IS CLARIFIED.  IT WOULD NOT BE PRUDENT TO RECLAIM THEM.

THE NEW PRIORITIZATION WOULD BE A 'A(X)' WHICH MEANS STATE LIABILITY IF RECLAMATION WERE TO PROCEED.

properties.Directions: RT. 611 SE OF LURAY, VIRGINIA, 1 MILE SOUTH OF SITE INTERSECTION WITH RT. 669.
properties.OlacNotes:
ENVIRONMENTAL AND PUBLIC HEALTH AND SAFETY HAZARDS EXIST DUE TO THE MINE SITE BEING UTILIZED AS AN ILLEGAL DUMP AND THE 70' VERTICAL HIGHWALLS WHICH EXIST.  GIVEN A RATING OF 'NR' AS THE LANDOWNER IS NOT INTERESTED IN RECLAIMING THE AREA UNTIL "HADES FREEZES OVER."

RECLAMATION IS NOT RECOMMENDED DUE TO PROBABLE REMINING.

properties.OlacNotes:
RECLAIMED
TONCRAE MINE

Merged with DMM9282 on 2/27/2017, record by Bishop (DMME)

     Reclamation is recommended to minimize the environmental and public health and safety hazards associated with the site. A grant has been submitted to the NPS program to assist with reclamation cost and is expected to be funded. Reclamation would involve shaft closure, wetland construction, stream diversion, and mine tailing reclamation.

From town of Floyd, VA, take 221 South for approx. 23 miles and look for 668 North.  Take 668 North to 812.  Look on right sid of road in field.

From the town of Newcastle, (route 311 north), continue on 311.  Before you reach town of Paint Bank (with very obvious switchback) turn left onto road 602.  Go about 1/4 to 1/2 mile.  Look on right for old trail.  Follow trail by the map to its end.  Site is at the end of the trail.

From I81, take 311 north to town of Paint Bank .  At town, look for general store on left.  Sites are on right side of road.  Follow grassy road on right cross a small creek.  Sites are near creek on small knob.

From Waynesbro leave the city going East on SR 622, about 1 mile from edge of town make a left onto Walden Lane. Procede on dirt road to a sharp left. Entering the forest here it is about .5 miles directly "upslope". Within sight of the crown of the hill.
Go down route 57 to enter Fairystone State Park (route 346).  Turn left at office and follow road leading down hill.  Bear left go past old bridge on trail.  Site on left.
From I81, take 250 west. about 2 miles west of Churchville, 42 south joins with 250. the site is located to the left of this junction.

From I81 take the 250 west exit to churchville. turn left on 42 south in churchville. turn lift in the high school parking lot. from the lot walk across the cow pasture about 100 yards south twords a clift. the site is part of the clift.

from I64 take 522 south exit . stay on 522 untill rt. 6 east. from 6 east make a right on to 690 south. Cross the James River. make a left on 602 east. then a right on 605. the site is on the left side of the road across from a race car track. there is a old dirt road, which may be hadr to see from 605, but it will lead you to the site.

From I64 take the 605 south exit and turn right. go all the way down 605 untill about 1/2 mile from the flivanna Co. line. you will be able to see the green  county sign. turn left on a dirt road. it is next to a house and is is the last dirt road before the county line. go all the was down this dirt road untill you reach the steam. there is a bridge but it is not crossable. the site is right of the road, down the hill, and next to another little stream. notice that there are sevral pits in the area! be carfull! vary carfull!

Note:  Latitude and Longitude for this site are from the path that turns in off of 678.

From McDowell Virginia:

Some advice.  Take a quadrangle map with you with the site on it when you are trying to find this one.  It is not that easy to find.

Take route 678 heading Southwest of McDowell for approximately 3.5 miles.  You will pass Route 615 on your right while driving.  Approximately 1 mile past Route 615 you will come upon a road/path leading off of the left hand side of the road (If you come to a place called  Clover Creek you have gone a little too far).  Take the path.  This path will go straight, then off to the left, then straight again (I believe it crossed a stream somewhere in the process).  Once the path straightens out keep going approximately 200-300 yards looking to the left side of the path.  The quarry is located on the left hand side of the path.  It is pretty big and you can easily see it from the path.

From I64 take the 605 south exit and turn right. go all the way down 605 untill about 1/2 mile from the flivanna Co. line. you will be able to see the green  county sign. turn left on a dirt road. it is next to a house and is is the last dirt road before the county line. go all the was down this dirt road untill you reach the steam. there is a bridge but it is not crossable. the site is right of the road, down the hill, and next to another little stream. notice that there are sevral pits in the area! be carfull! vary carfull!

From Charlottesville take 29 South about 10 miles, to SR 692, turn left on to 692. This road turns into SR 712. Follow SR 712 till it passes under tain tracks, .25 miles after passing under the train tracks turn right onto Laird Road (Laird and Co. Apple Products). Follow Laird Road back and to Wilder Lane and cross rail road tracks again, a right. Follow Wilder Lane up hill and far right as you can go. At the end of the road walk right around the mountain till finding a fire road leading directly away fromt he apple orchard below. The fire road passes between a trench and a pit on the site. The fire road should bring you to the top of the hill.

From Covesville on Route 29:

Head to Covesville on 29 South out of Charlottesville.  When on the South end of Covesville take a left onto Covesville Rd.  Go for approximately .4 mile and then take another Left onto Covesville Lane.  Continue all of the way to the end of Covesville Lane and you will come to a house.  This is a good place to park your car.  The man and woman who live in the house are very nice.  To find the actual mines I would recommend taking a GPS unit.  The mines are far up the hill.  Both are off to the left of the house.  One by about 50 yards to left (100 yards uphill), the other by about 200-300 yards to the left (300-400 yards uphill) (Note: these distances are estimates).

From The town of Doe Hill:

Travel approximately 1 mile Southeast of Doe Hill on Route 654.  Take a left onto Route 619.  Travel approximately ¾-1 mile down 619 until you reach Lynn Rock Church/Chapel.  Once there will want to walk down the road about 100-200 yards.  Looking on the right hand side of the road you will see a small stream.  If you look up and down the stream there will be a very large pipe (under bridge) coming into the stream.  If you stand in the stream where there is a drainage pipe and look up to your right you should be able to see the quarry.  It is extremely small.  I think that it may have been a test site.

Note:  Latitude and Longitude Measurements for this site were taken from HWY 678.

From McDowell Virginia:

Some advice.  Take a quadrangle map with you with the site on it when you are trying to find this one.  It is not that easy to find.

Take route 678 heading Southwest of McDowell for approximately 3.5 miles.  You will pass Route 615 on your right while driving.  Approximately 1 mile past Route 615 you will come upon a road/path leading off of the left hand side of the road (If you come to a place called  Clover Creek you have gone a little too far).  Take the path.  This path will go straight, then off to the left, then straight again (I believe it crossed a stream somewhere in the process).  Once the path straightens out as soon as you get into the woodsy section of the path stop and look off to your left.  This is where sites 903 and 904 are located.  You will be able to see the bottom of an old mine shaft at the bottom of the hill, just across a stream.  If you climb up the hill approximately 100 yards, you will be able to see the top of the shaft.

From I-64

Take VA 608 (exit #91) towards Fishersville/Stuarts Draft.  Turn Right onto VA 608.  Keep straight on 608.  Go approximately eleven miles down route 608.  Take a left onto route 612.  Go about 1 mile down route 612 and then take a right onto route 784.  Go about 2/10 of a mile down route 784 (also called Pine Bluff Road).  You will come to address 451 Pine Bluff Road.  This is the driveway you want.  If you go up the driveway and walk back to the right of the driveway you will find the quarry.  This site is very well maintained and has grass growing in the bottom of the quarry.

From I-64

Take VA 608 (exit #91) towards Fishersville/Stuarts Draft.  Turn Right onto VA 608.  Keep straight on 608.  Go approximately twelve miles down route 608.  On the left hand side of the road you will see a sign for Meadow Run Dairy farm.  This is the driveway that you want to turn down.  Turn down this driveway and go until you arrive at a house/farming operation.  Once there if you go behind the main barn where all the cows are fed you will see a small stream.  Follow this stream to the left of the driveway for about 1/10 of a mile and you will see the site in the field.

From Columbia VA:

Word of Advice:  Take a GPS unit to help you find this site.  It is in the woods.

Head out of Columbia going West-Northwest on Route 6.  You will pass through the town of Holmhead.  Once passed Holmhead take a left onto Route 624.  You will pass Gravel Hill Church.  Continue for a few hundred yards and you will see a path on the left hand side of the road.  Take this path until it runs out.  Once the path runs out continue into the woods for approximately 50 yards in the same direction as the path would take you if it continued going straight.  You should run into a hole in the ground.  This is the site.

properties.Directions: From Grottoes take Browns Gap Road (rt 663)east.  Just before the junction with Port Republic Road, there is a gated fire road leading south.  In approximately one mile go cross-country dead reckoning to the mine.
properties.OlacNotes: Mine consist of pit on knoll (1 - 38.24343,-78.77617), a smaller pit behind it (2 - 38.24347, -78.77599), a cascade of three pits down a slope from 3 (38.24346, -78.77583)to 4 (38.24356, -78.77579), and small prospect holes at 5(38.24384, -78.77586) and 6 (38.24313, -78.77634)

properties.Directions: Take Browntown Road (rt 649) south of Front Royal.  Take Cardinal Wind Road east for approximately 1 mile.  Then go cross-country to mine site at the end of buttress ridge.
properties.MineName: Virginia and Pittsburgh Copper Co. Prospect

properties.Directions: Traveling north from Front Royal cross the North Fork of the Shenandoah, turn right on Guard Hill Road.  The site is along the road.

From the mall northwest of the rt 340 Interstate 66 exchange, go to the northwest corner of the parking lot in front of Target (south end of the mall). Cross a cable and follow the gravel road down over Crooked Run on a rickety bridge.  Half way up the hill, an eroded dirt road to the south leads to the quarry.
properties.OlacNotes:
Property owner same as owner of the mall.

Property borders Virginia Department of Highways (VDH) property along Interstate 66

properties.Directions: The mall northeast of the I-66 rt. 340 interchange us built over a portion of the Riverton Mine
properties.OlacNotes: Evidence of the mine no longer exists. Local Images on the Warren County GIS web site show the extent of mine before mall built (see photos).

properties.Directions: ROUTE 3 BETWEEN KING GEORGE AND FREDERICKSBURG.
Behind 1455 Seven Fountains Road, Fort Valley.
In Little Fort Recreation Area, behind shed.
Directly besides and beneath Mine Shaft Lane
The Furnace is located on the north side of the Mine Run Lane just east of the George Washington National Forest boundary.
On Forest Road 66, near Powell Fort Camp.  The site is before a gate and there is a turn out for vehicles.
North of Forest Road 66 near the open gate at Mud Gap.  To reach the mine one must go cross-country to the coordinates.
Along Forest Road 66

On Woodstock Tower Road (rt. 758) south of the ridge and just north of Little Fort Recreation Area, turn east down to a parking lot. Cross a gate and continue northeast on foot on a road.  The collapsed shaft is on the east side of the road.
properties.OlacNotes: Possiblely related to Cameron Prospect (DMM14057)

properties.Directions: Take forest road 66 to its northern terminus just past Powells Fort Camp. Continue on foot past the gate.  Go for approximately 1.5 miles and the mines are to the east.  Cut 12 crosses the road.

From Elizabeth Furnace Picnic Area take the blue-blazed Tuscarora Trail west.  At the junction with the orange-blazed Massanutten Trail continue on the Tuscarora.  The trail passes through the mines at site 20-21 and 7.
From the Elizabeth Furnace Group Campground, take the purple-blazed Mudhole Gap Trail, a gated ATV road.  The trail crosses the mine in approximately 2 miles.

From Elizabeth Furnace take the Charcoal Trail to the placard explaining a mine trench (DMM14075).  Beyond (east) of the placard, the blue-blazed Tuscaroara Trail comes in from the west and heads off east.  Ignoring these trails, go straight on unmarked old wagon road.  The prospects are on either side of this road.
Site is on Fort Valley Road (rt. 678) across from the Elizabeth Furnace Picnic Area.

Across from Elizabeth Furnace Picnic Area, west of Fort Valley Road (rt.678), take a spur road up to a spring house. Continue up road to second spring house. Follow drainage behind 2nd spring house on remaints of an old wagon road. Cut intersects drainage.
Southeast of Strasburg on rt. 55, turn north on Natures Way Lane and go to end.  The remains of the shale pit (now pasture) is in the northeast corner of the fence row.
properties.OlacNotes: A portion of the pit may be on the property of Kenneth & Tammy Monkman, 252 Natures Way Lane, Strasburg, VA, 22657.

properties.Directions: On the property line between 119 Lakeland Pines Drive and 16575 Moneta Road at Smith Mountain Lake.
properties.OlacNotes: Muscovite  Mica found here with non-commercial feldspar.

properties.Directions: South of switchback in the Woodstock Gap Road (rt. 758) on western slope of Powell Mountain.
Site is behind (west of) the Pickett Spring Parking Area.
Elizabeth Furnace Picnic Area off rt. 678.

properties.Directions: Powhatan Limestone Co. Quarry is located from the intersection of  I-81 and the John Marshall Highway (rt. 48/55).  Take US Rte. 55 SW for about 1 mile. Turn left onto Powhatan Road.

properties.Directions:
East of rt. 11 within the boundaries of Toms Brook.

properties.OlacNotes: Same mining operation as DMM14054, different HUC.  Presently operating under permit 05667AB.

properties.Directions: In Broadway, on property bounded by East Springbrook Road and Brethern Road. Behind Linville Creek Brethern Church.

Concord Mine continues on DMM14203.

properties.Directions: The site is south of Concord on the Columbia Gas of Virginia Pipeline between Booth Road (rt. 657) and Ruckers Road (rt. 775).  The quarry is through a gate just north of the pipeline.

Produced Dimension Stone.

-78.97469

south east of Mine Mountain Road between North Lake and Pine Lake.

properties.OlacNotes: Captured drill bit found at 38.98249, -78.38784.  Quarry is in a landslide. View taken from 38.98227, -78.38808 shows landslide. The headwall left by sliding away of steeply dipped limestone may have been mistaken for another quarry MRV209B_304.

properties.Directions: From Edinburg take Water Street (SR 760) for approximately 0.75 mile. The pit is on the inside northeast corner of the meander of North Fork of Shenandoah River.

On the Charcoal Trail at Elizabeth Furnace.

Driving southwest towards Paint bank, turn on left onto Rt. 311, then turn right onto Rt. 17. The mines are north of the road, accessed by hiking into national forest.

Driving south over the Robert E. Lee bridge, turn right onto Riversider Dr. Turn into the parkign lot on the right after about 0.3 miles.

From Rt. 11 turn east onto Rt. 601 (Shadwell Dr.). The site is approximately 1/2 mile fro Rt. 11, east of Hollins College.  To access the site, walk  about 200' through the woods. The site is located on Tinker Creek.

THE COMMITTEE WAS MIXED ONT HE PRIORITY RATING WITH THE MAJORITY RECOMMENDING A 'B' PRIORITY DUE TO THE FEELING THAT OTHER SITES POSED A GREATER HAZARD TO THE ENVIRONMENT.  SEVERAL COMMENTED THAT IT WAS THE LANDOWNER'S RESPONSIBILITY TO FENCE THE QUARRY. 

PLAN OF RECLAMATION WOULD BE TO FENCE THE MINE SITE TO MINIMIZE THE FALL HAZARDS.  PLACE WARNING SIGNS. (BISHOP)

PARTIALLY VEGETATED OPEN AREA OFF SIDE OF RT 220. MOST OF SITE HAS GRASS AND SOEM PINE TREES ON IT, BUT AREA CLOSEST TO ROAD HAS TRASH AND IS UNVEGEATED.  HOUSEHOLD APPLIANCES ON SITE HAVE BEEN USED FOR TARGET PRACTICE. 

#2- ROADSIDE SHALE PIT ALONG 220.  SITE SEEMED TO BE SPLIT INTO TWO LEVELS.  TOP LEVEL WAS 100' LONG X 30' WIDE X 10' DEEP, WHILE THE SECOND CONVERED ABOUT HALF THE AREA OF THE FIRST.  MUCH OF AREA WAS BARE AND UNVEGETATED, BUT ONE SECTION ALONG THE ROAD BETWEEN THE TWO LEVELS, HAD THICK VEGETATION SIMILAR TO THAT USED ON ORPHAN LAND SITES.  SOME TRASH AND HOUSEHOLD APPLIANCES HAD BEEN DISPOSED OF ON THE SITE.

properties.Directions: From US 29 heading south, take state road 683 for about 3.5 miles south until a private road on the left.  Take this road for about half a mile, the site is just 50 feet off of the road on the left (southeast).

From US 501, take state road 660 east for 2 miles until an intersection with an unmarked road and the railroad tracks.  Take the private road to the left (north) for just over .5 miles, the site will be .2 miles into the woods (northwest).
From US 460, heading west, take state road 662 for about 1.25 miles.  Make a right on a private drive (Sumter Lane) and drive for about 0.1 miles, the site is 100 feet on the right.

From Columbia Furnace take route 676 west.  Take left fork onto route 717.  After 2 miles turn left onto route 690.  Travel 1.5 miles to stream crossing.  After stream crossing turn left onto forest service road.  Travel 1/4 mile down the forest service road and park.  Sites are on the top of 3 mile mountain which is on the left.  Climb up anywhere and locate the trail on the northwest side of the ridge.  Site is located just north of rock outcrop on the east side of the trail.

From Columbia Furnace take route 676 west.  Take left fork onto route 717.  After 2 miles turn left onto route 690.  Travel 1.5 miles to stream crossing.  After stream crossing turn left onto forest service road.  Travel 1/4 mile down the forest service road and park.  Sites are on the top of 3 mile mountain which is on the left.  Climb up anywhere and locate the trail on the northwest side of the ridge.  Site is located 1/4 mile north of rock outcrop along the trail.

Take US29 south towards Lynchburg.  Then merge onto US460 east.  Turn onto road 501 (Campbell Highway).  Then turn right on 670 (Sunnymeade Rd).  Follow the railroad tracks for 1 mile then hike up the drainage that runs northwest.  The site is about a quarter of a mile up the drainage.

from the intersection of 626 and 604 on the quad, drive approximately 1mile NW until an access road "v"'s off to the right.  Follow the access road 1/4 mile until a road "T"'s off to the left (NW).  Follow the access road 1 mile until reacching a crossroad.  Continue to walk straight down the road (NE) for another 1/4 mile.  Walk directly N into the woods to the top of the hill to the site.

from the intersection of 722 and 646 on the quad, there is an access road on the NW side of 722 directly across from where 646 intersects with 722.  Follow the road approximately 1/2 mile (you will pass a quarry on the right, site 101 and a quarry marked on the map on the left) until the road branches to the right (south).  Follow this branch to the bottom of the quarry.

From this point, drive about 0.5 miles until the access until it forks.  At this point, the quarry will be on the right side of the road about 50 yards to the north.  It is marked as a body of water on the topo.

Site is 100 yds South on logging road and about 15 ft to the East side of the path (left side).

Take this road North for approximately 1 mile.  If you reach the intersection of County Road 721 and County Route 605 you have gone too far.  Site is on the South side of County Road 721 about 100 yards from the road.

At the intersection of State Route 60 South and Route 26, take 26 South.  Take 26 South until the intersection with County Route 611 and take 611 West.  Go until you reach County Route 721 North.   Take this road North for approximately 1 mile.  If you reach the intersection of County Road 721 and County Route 605 you have gone too far.  Site is on the North side of County Road 721 about 200 yards from the road.

Take State Route 56 to County Road 722.  Take County Route 722 East until the intersection with County Route 646.  There is an access road to the west of County Route 646 that leads directly to the site.  It is about 1/8 – ¼ mile up the access road.

From the intersection of 26 and 684.  Drive 1.5 miles west on 684 until a logging road is reached.  Take a left on this road, and drive 0.2 miles until this road intersects with a Jeep trail. Walk southwest until the road comes to an end.  Site 309 will be 150 yards to the west.

-29 South
-60 East
-right onto 600
-right onto 622
-left onto road with Greif Bros. Corporation sign
-0.2 mi down road, turn left onto gravel road (sign says Gate 2)
-about 1/4 mi past fence (down and up hill), sites begin to left of gravel road about 20 feet into woods

From the intersection of 626 and 743 (driving on 626 coming from 56), turn left (NW) onto 743 and drive 1.4miles until a creek crosses over the road and the road ends.  Walk 0.1 miles down the access road until you come to an open field. 408 will be on the right (NE) on the stream bank next to mound that obviously does not belong.
properties.OlacNotes: OLP to look at site.

properties.Directions: From 29 S, take 60 E.  Turn right onto Route 26, and then right again onto 605.  Turn Right onto Route 623 and travel 1 mile.  Turn down Jeep trail and travel .25 mile.  Site is approximately 200 yds to the north.
properties.OlacNotes: RE-EVALUATE SITE

properties.Directions: Take US 605 to Beckman, turn left on US683 go 1/4 mile turn into old road. Go another 1/4 mile turn into driveway. Go to cabin/house aprox 80 ft south of cabin

From the town of Stonewall, which is adjacent to the intersection of state routes 608 and 721, take 721 north.  Sites are on the northwest side of 721, just past the junction of state route 605.  They are within 20ft of the road.

The site is 200yrds from intersection of 602 on left, starting about 250 yards south from the road and the Amherst Wayside on route 60.  There is a logging access road that leads back into the woods, and the sites are distributed 20 yards west of it.
The site is 200yrds from intersection of 602 on left.  The site is about 40 yards into the woods from the road and the Amherst Wayside on route 60.

From 684 and 26, go right(west) on 684, turn left on dirt road after 1 mile.  Then turn right at driveway amd proceed 1 mile down driveway to the end.  Wlak over the hill on the left (west) and site is on the river side of the hill about 50 ft to the stream below,

Follow Route 60 West from Route 29 at Amherst.  Follow Route 60 West and turn right on to State Route 26.  Follow 26 for about 2 miles to Virginia State Route 684.  Follow this road for about 3 miles.  At the fork at 3 miles, turn right on the dirt road and follow to the end.  Walk directly West for .1 mile and climb a small hill.  Descend half way down the hill to the site.

From 29 South, turn onto 60 East. Turn Right onto Route 622 South.  Turn Left onto Route 624 (Bateau Lane) and travel approximately 1.1 miles down road.  Sites are 50 yards (130)and .25 miles (129) respectively along stream on North side of road.
From 29 South, take 60 East.  Turn Right onto Route 622 South.  Site is just before intersection of 622 and 776 (Walnut Springs Rd) on South side of road.
From 29 South, take 60 East.  Turn Right onto Route 622 South. Turn left onto Route 776 (Walnut Springs Rd) and travel 0.8 miles.  Site is 10 yds south of sharp right turn in road.
properties.OlacNotes: RE-EVALUATE SITE

properties.Directions: Take US 657 north to US 558. Go east aprox 1/2 mile on US 558. Look for 2 large jeep trails on left.  Take first jeep trail aprox 3/4 mile to site

Follow Route 60 West from Route 29 at Amherst.  Follow Route 60 West and turn right on to State Route 26.  Follow 26 for about 2 miles to Virginia State Route 684.  Follow this road for about 3 miles.  At the fork at 3 miles, turn right on the dirt road and follow to the end.  Walk about .3 miles North East up a slight gradient.  Walk about .1 miles North West from this spot.  The site is across a stream
properties.OlacNotes: RE-EVALUATE SITE

properties.Directions: US route 60 east to state route 600.  Shortly before intersection with state route 622, there are a series of logging roads on the eastern side of the road.  Take the last one before the intersection of 600 and 622.  It appears as a long dirt road across a clearcut.  Follow across clearcut to edge of pine thicket.  Site 905 is on the right side of the road.

US route 60 east to state route 600, to state route 622 east.  The sites are shortly before the intersection of this road and state route 601, on the southeast side of the road (right).  They are directly behind the house adjacent to this intersection, with several school buses along the ridge line.
properties.OlacNotes: RECLAIMED  OLP-02-01

properties.Directions:
-29 South
-60 East
-right onto 622 South
-left onto 624 / Bateau Lane
-0.7 miles down road
-follow creek on north (left) side of road, sites are to the left of creek
From the intersection of 683 and 605.  Drive south 0.6 miles on 683.  There will be a cow pasture on the west side of 683 where site 301 can be found.  The site is about 25 yards west of the road.

Follow Route 60 West from Route 29 at Amherst.  Follow Route 60 West and turn right on to State Route 26.  Follow 26 for about 2 miles to Virginia State Route 684.  Follow this road for about 3 miles.  At the fork at 3 miles, turn right on the dirt road and follow to the end.  Walk about .3 miles North East up a slight gradient.  The site is next to a very steep hill and a stream.
From 29 South, take 60 East.  Take a right onto Route 600. Then take a right onto Route 823.  Travel 0.1 miles.  Site is 20 yards east of road.
From 29 South, take 60 East.  Take a right onto Route 600. Then take a right onto Route 823.  Travel 0.1 miles.  Site is 50 yards east of road.

Take 29 South to 60 East. Turn Right onto 622 South.  At Stapleton, turn Right onto Route 624. Travel .8 miles and park at logging road on north side of road (across from a picnic area).  Travel approximately .5 miles up logging road to find prospects.

Take 29 South to Route 60 East.  Turn right onto Route 600 (South), and turn right again onto 823.  Turn right (West) onto Route 622 and travel aprox. 4 miles.  Take logging road to the North side of the road (several yards before small stream).  Drive or walk NE up logging road for about 1/4 mile.  Walk up the side of the mountain.  There will be an access road running around the mountain about 3/4 the way to the top.  Travel to the South slope and the site is just south of the access road, about 15 ft.
Take us 29 south to US 56. Take us 56 aprox 1.2 miles. Site is on east side of road
Take US 29 to Us 56. Go east on US 56 , then go south on 647. Take 647 to Us 626. Go west on 626 aprox 2 miles look for old road on left. Site within 30 yrds of road.

-29 South
-56 West
-Right onto 655
-after intersection with 672:
-left onto gravel driveway with 2 mailboxes (818 - M. G. McMurry; John C. Par)
-gravel driveway turns into dirt road past house, continue about 50 ft; quarry on left through woods, visible from trail

-29 South
-665 East
-right onto 661
-left to stay on 661
-right onto 654
-just before bridge over Tye River, follow overgrown trail along river on right side of road
properties.OlacNotes: GARNET

properties.Directions: Take US 29 south to US 60. Go east on 60 to US 600. Go aprox 1/2 mile take road on right. Road is a currently used as a driveway. Go 1/2 mile down drive way. Site on left.
Take US 29 south to US 60. Go east on 60 to us 600. Go south on 600 to US 622. Go north aprox 2 miles . Sites are about 2000 ft on north  side of road.
Follow Virginia State Route 659 3.8 miles from US 60.  At the bend in the road, turn right on to a dirt road.  Follow this road for .6 miles to the site.  The site is 15 yards off the dirt road.
from the intersection of 605 and 644 on the quad, follow 605 0.1mi
Follow Virginia State Route 659 3.8miles from US 60.  At the bend in the road, turn right onto a dirt road.  Follow the road for .6 miles, the site is about 50 yards off the road.
Follow Virginia Route 622 two miles west from the fork of Virginia Route 622 and 656.  At this point, walk up a hill .25 miles due North.  The site is on top of the hill.
from the intersection of 601 and 657, drive 1.1mi SE down 657 until the road runs right next to a creek.  Park and walk 0.1 miles East uphill to the site.
from the intersection of 622 and 600, take 622 SE approximately 1.5miles.  Site 808 is located 0.2m NW of the road.  Site 809 is located 0.2mi NE of 808

-29 South
-60 East
-right onto 600
-right onto 622
-right onto 624
-after 2nd bridge, pull off road
-follow overgrown road about 150 yds, turn right and head up thru valley
-sites 102-108 lie very close together towards NE direction
properties.OlacNotes: Iron Furnace

properties.Directions: Site 3/4 mi from Dillwyn.  Start at intersection of 20 and 15,  go east on 15.  Turn right on 1017 go 1/4 mile.  Walk off road to the right past other sites following gold Mine Branch.  After about 1/2 mi.  its over the hill to the right.

Start from the intersection of 626 and 60.  Take 60 west 1/4 mi.  Stop on the left side at a small access road with a gate.  Site is in the clear cut area.  Take dirt trail to its end then proceed 30 ft to the SW.
properties.OlacNotes: Pit filled in with timbers in clear cut area close to the road.

properties.Directions: From 626 and 60, go 1/4 mi on 60 west.  On the right turn onto a dirt road.  Drive 1/2 mile up the road .  Site is on the right about 50 meters from the road and 50 meters away from the other site(103).
properties.OlacNotes: small shaft in the middle of dense woods

properties.Directions: From the intersection of 768 and 622, go north on 768.  Adit is on the side of the road 2 yds from the road on the right.
50ft from highway 656 at the west end of Gladstone to the left of the Post Office.  Site is just 50ft off highway.

Take US 20 south to Us 617. Go west on 617 to 631. Go aprox 2 miles south on 631 look for Driveway on right ( currently owned by tree farm) go 1/4 mile on drive way. Site is aprox 1000 yards south of driveway.

Take US 20 south to US 617. Go east on 617 turn right on 682. Take 682 to its end. Then turn east on 631. Look for sharpe curve to the south, there is a jeep trail on the left at this point in the road. Take jeep trail aprox 1/4 mile. site is 1000 yards east of the trail
Take US 626 to us 607. Go aprox 1/2 mile on 607. Site is on right side of road on steep bank that goes along the river.

-29 South
-after intersection with 651, site is on northbound side of road, up hill
-site directly below phone lines running N-S at the top of the hill

Take State Route 56 east to County Route 626.  Take County Route 626 East until it intersects with County Route 743.  Take Route 743 North for 1.4 miles until the road ends abruptly at a creek.  Walk approximately ½ mile along the washed out road until you reach an old summer home.  Behind this house is a drainage.  Follow the drainage for about 40 feet.  Up the side of the drainage to the left about 20-30 feet is the site.

At the intersection of State Route 60 South and Route 26, take 26 South.  Take 26 South until the intersection with County Route 611 and take 611 West.  Go until you reach the intersection with County Road 667.  Take this road to the North until it intersects with County Route 605.  Take Route 605 west for 1/8 to ¼ of a mile.  Two driveways go off the South side of the road.  Directly after the second driveway and about 20 feet off the road is the site.
North and west of Black Oak Ridge and Route 725.
properties.OlacNotes: Processed into Agricultural Lime.

properties.Directions: Take State Route 56 east to County Route 647 south.  Take County Route 647 until the intersection with County Route 722 west.  Drive on county route 722 west for slightly less than 1 mile to a logging road to the east.  Take this road for approximately ½ mile.  The quarry is 200-300 yards south of the trail.

Take State Route 56 east to County Route 647 south.  Take County Route 647 until the intersection with County Route 626.  Take Route 626 west to Norwood.  There is a driveway approximately 1000 feet before county route 655.  Take the driveway to the north.  Follow it until you reach an overgrown portion where the driveway curves to the west. Go along this overgrown area for 1/4 mile.  The site is approximately 50 feet to the east of this road.

Take State Route 60 east until approximately ½ to ¾ mile from county route 657.  There is a hand-drawn dotted line on the map that indicates a road, but this road does not lead where the line says it does.  Once you find this intersection, go into the woods about ¼ mile and you will find the prospect.

Take State Route 60 East until the intersection with county route 622 south.  Take this road until you reach the town of Allen’s Creek.  Before you cross the creek, you will see county route 768.  Take it for approximately ¼ of a mile.  Stop the car and climb up the nearly vertical hill until you reach a field of prospects.
Take County Route 626 South from Howardsville to the intersection with County Route 644.  Take County Route 644 east for 1.5 miles.  The site is about 1/8 mile up the gated dirt road on the left.
Along the roadside of Rt 762
On Rt 733 at Steptoe Hill

Take Route 29 South to Amherst and take Route 60 East.  Turn right onto Route 600 (South).  Travel past the intersection with 823.  Park where road turns sharp to the right and an old logging road goes to the left.  The prospect is right to the left of that intersection about 20 ft and the adits are about 50 yds South of the prospect near stream.
from 626 and 655, go 655 N turn right to stay on 655 go 1 mile.  Park car 100m before bridge.  Go up hill to the left.  707 is on the hill.

-29 South
-60 East
-0.8 miles east of intersection with 67 on north side of road

At the intersection of State Route 60 South and Route 26, take 26 South.  Take 26 South until the intersection with County Route 611 and take 611 West.  Go until you reach County Route 721 North.   Take this road North for approximately 1.5 miles.  The site is on the South side of the road directly off the roadside next to a small stream.

From the town of Howardsville, take state route 626 in a southwest direction for about a mile.  On the southeast side of the road will be a wooden gate across a tree-lined driveway.  Following this back will take you past a seasonally occupied property overlooking the James River and railroad tracks.  The site is about a third of a mile south, following the railroad tracks.

Follow Route 60 West from Route 29 at Amherst.  Follow Route 60 West and turn right on to State Route 26.  Follow 26 for about 2 miles to Virginia State Route 283.  Follow Route 283 for about 4 miles until it merges with Route 605.  Follow Route 605 for about 2.1 miles to a road on the right.  Continue on this road about .45 miles to the end.  Ascend up a hill to the North East to a ridge.  Walk in the North East Direction to the bottom of the hill.  Ascend up the hill for about .1 miles in the North West Direction to the site on the ridge of the hill.

From Gladstone go west on 656 to the west end of town.  Park car at curve and follow railroad tracks 1/4 mile along the river.  After 1/4 mile turn to the right and follow the creek till it splits.  Follow the right fork to the addit which is on the left bank.

At the intersection of State Route 60 South and Route 26, take 26 South.  Take 26 South until the intersection with County Route 611 and take 611 West.  Go until you reach the intersection with County Road 667.  Take this road to the North until it intersects with County Route 605.  Take Route 605 west for ½	mile.  As you begin to go down a hill you will see a prospect that is part of site MRV105B206 on the North side of the road.  MRV105B205 is situated directly across the road to the south about 10 feet from the side of the road.

Take State Route 60 east until the intersection with county route 657 south.  Take 657 until the intersection with 622.  This intersection is a sharp turn to the southeast and turns quickly to the north.  Follow it until you reach a populated area 0.9 miles before Allen’s Creek.  Once at this populated area, you have to walk about ½ mile to the north from the road.  You will cross Dry Branch Creek at the northernmost point of a meander.  The site is up a steep hill to the west.  There is a large pasture in the flat area at the top of the hill.
On Wind Field Farms property off Rt 734
Cross Goose Creek from Rt 733 into site
Enter from Rt 15 onto private road

Take State Route 60 East until the intersection with county route 622 south.  Take it until the intersection with county route 656 south.  Take 656 to Gladstone.  Stop the car at the edge of town and follow the railroad tracks to the west for about 800-1000 feet.  The site is to the north of the tracks.

At the intersection of State Route 60 South and Route 26, take 26 South.  Take 26 South until the intersection with County Route 611 and take 611 West.  Go until you reach County Route 721 North.   Take this road North for approximately 1 mile.  You will reach the intersection with County Route 605.  Go North on Route 605 for about 1/8 of a mile.  The road rests almost directly on top of the highwall to the East.  There is a driveway to the East slightly past the highwall that leads directly down the hill and to the highwall.

Take State Route 60 East until the intersection with county route 626 north.  About ¾ of a mile before you reach Buffalo Station there is a trail to the south east.  Follow it for approximately ½ to ¾ mile until you reach Carter Creek.  The adit is on the East bank of the creek.

Take State Route 60 East until the intersection with county route 626 north.  About ¾ of a mile before you reach Buffalo Station there is a trail to the south east.  Follow it for approximately ½ to ¾ mile until you reach Carter Creek.  About 700 feet upstream and across the creek is the shaft.

Take State Route 60 East until the intersection with county route 626 north.  About ¾ of a mile before you reach Buffalo Springs, there is an access road to the west.  Between the access road and 626 is the shaft.  It is about 50-100 feet from the junction of the two roads.

Take State Route 60 East until the intersection with county route 626 north.  About 1 mile before you reach Buffalo Springs, there is an old trailer with a outhouse.  Behind the trailer about 100 feet up the hill is the prospect.
On US 15 @ Oatlands
Enter Potomac Station development east of Leesburg on Rt7
properties.OlacNotes: Site was reclaimed(fenced) adequately by landowners association.  Good fence.  Site is monitored by the Association.

properties.Directions: From intersection of 647 and 56 head north up 647.  Site is 2 miles right off of road to the left (west).
From intersection of 601 and 604 take 604 north for a mile and a half.  Turn onto gravel road on right, site is at end of road.
From the intersection of 667 and 605, go north/west on 605.  Turn right on 624.  Turn onto driveway on left and go up the hill behind the house.  Site is on north face near the top of the hill.

From the intersection of 721 and 611, go west on 721.  Turn right on the road after county road 624.  Keep to the right past two split offs.  At the last fork in the road with the gate, go up the jeep trail.  Go for 1/2 mile on jeep trail.  Site is 100 ft to the right of the trail.

From Charlottesville:
Take 29 S to Rt. 60 East in Amherst.  Take a right onto 600.  Travelled approximately 15 minutes before parking opposite a house on the right side of the road.  The house number was #2294

Take 29 S to Amherst exit, then 60 E for 5-8 miles.  Take a right turn onto route 600 and follow for several miles until it meets route 622.  Turn around and turn right onto the first access/logging road.  This road will fork on the other side of the hill; take a left.  Travel for 200-250 ft.  Site will be 75 ft east (right) on a hillslope.

Take 29 S to 60 E at Amherst.  Once you cross the James River, take 26 S towards Appomattox.  Take an immediate right onto 605.  Follow this road for about 10 miles until you get to 667.  Route 667 will be a left hand turn, but on the right side will be two houses with a little road to a pasture.  100 ft behind the house to the right (in the woods) is where the site starts.
From intersection of 622 and 656 take 622 east for two miles.  Park on curve, site 50 yards North of road.
Enter Potomac Station development from Rt7
Enter from Rt 688
On Rt 671 at the Potomac River
Enter from Rt 674
side of Rt 772

From Charlottesville, take 29 South to 60 East.  After passing by 657, follow a trail on the left side of the road.  The trail follows along the top of the ridge and the site will be about 2/5 mile down the trail on the left side.

From Esmont take 715 north a very short distance(two hundred yards or so) to Saint Ann's Parish and park. Accross the road to the east is an access road that goes into the property wherer the site is located. It was a tree farm at the time of the inspection. As the road makes a right bend a few hundred feet up from 715, slate debris becomes visible. About 20 yards further up the road the impounded quarry that is site 101 becomes visible through the woods to the left(North).

From Charlottesville, take 64 East to 15 South.  Take a right onto 617 and take another right on a road just after you pass by 631 on your left.  It will be about ¼ mile down this road on the left side.

In the town of Dillwyn, find Goldmine Rd., take it and turn onto Rt. 1017, which heads north. A short distance (a few hundred yards) along there is a long straight stretch, and halfway up it there are noticeable tailings piles on both sides of the road. Enter the woods to the right(NE) and follow the linear group of reclaimed Hobson Au mines. After topping the hill and beginning descent past site 406, enter the woods in the same NW bearing. As the floor of the woods turns to bottom lands and noticible ground disturbance thins, (sites 407 408) site 409 is a bit to the NNW on the far side of the bottomlands.

From the intersection of 626 and 743 (driving on 626 coming from 56), turn left (NW) onto 743 and drive 1.4miles until a creek crosses over the road and the road ends.  Walk 0.1 miles down the access road until you come to an open field. 409 can be seen across the creek from 408 to the N.  Cross the creek and walk 20yds N uphill to 409.  410 is located 20yds NNE of 409.  411 is located 10 yds SE of 410.

From 29 South, take 60 East.  Turn right onto Route 26, and then take another right onto Route 605. Turn onto Route 623.  Approximately 1 mile down Route 623, turn right onto a Jeep trail and travel for .25 mile.  Sites are approximately 200 yds to the North

Going South on Route 29, turn left onto 56 East.  Turn right onto 626 South.  Turn left onto logging road with sign reading Blue Moon Hunt Club.  Road has a gate up, so walk 1 mile down road to the train tracks, and walk 400 yds West along the tracks.  Sights are along tracks on the North side.

Follow Route 60 West from Route 29 at Amherst.  Follow Route 60 West and turn right on to State Route 26.  Follow 26 for about 2 miles to Virginia State Route 283.  Follow Route 283 for about 4 miles until it merges with Route 605.  Follow Route 605 for about 2.7 miles to a fork.  Take the right fork.  At about .4 miles down the road, walk about 50 yards off the right side of the road to the site.

Follow Route 60 West from Route 29 at Amherst.  Follow Route 60 West and turn right on to State Route 26.  Follow 26 for about 2 miles to Virginia State Route 283.  Follow Route 283 for about 4 miles until it merges with Route 605.  Follow Route 605 for about 2.1 miles to a road on the right.  Continue on this road about .45 miles to the end.  Ascend up a hill to the North East to a ridge.  Descend down the ridge about .1 miles to the site.

-29 South
-56 East
-about 3/4 mi past intersection with 646:
-at sharp left turn just before Mine Hill Road, go into the woods about 30 ft from the curve in the road

-29S to 60E
-right onto 600
-right onto 622
-right onto 624
--> follow creek north about 1/4 mi and pull off road after second bridge.
--> Follow an overgrown road approximately about 300 yards NE to the sites
From 29 S, take 56 West.  Right onto 655N.  After intersection with Route 672, the site is on the right at a curve in the road.

From intersection of 768 and 622, go north on 768 and stop at site 407.  Walk up Buck Mtn on the right to the top and find the trail that starts there. Site is between the trail and the drainage to the right.  Site is about 100yds. before intersection with older trail.

Take us 20 south to US 617. Take 617 east aprox 2 miles past eldridge Mill. Aprox 1/4 mile past Eldridge Mill look for jeep trail on left. Go 1/4 mile on jeep trail site is 200 ft on eastern side of trail
On Route 756 east of Bloomfield

Take State Route 56 east to County Route 647 south.  Take County Route 647 until the intersection with County Route 626.  Take Route 626 west until the intersection with county route 655 north after Norwood.  Go 1/8 mile on 655 and there will be an abandoned driveway to the north.  Follow it until you reach the abandoned house.  Cross Joe’s Creek to the North and follow the tributary that comes from the right when going upstream along Joe’s Creek.  Go about 500 feet up the tributary and the adit will be to the northeast.

At the intersection of State Route 60 South and Route 26, take 26 South.  Take 26 South until the intersection with County Route 611 and take 611 West.  Go until you reach the intersection with County Road 667.  Take this road to the North until it intersects with County Route 605.  Take Route 605 west for ½-5/8 mile.  There is an old overgrown access road to the south.  Walk along this road for approximately 200 feet and the site will be to the northwest.

Take State Route 60 east until the intersection with county route 606 south.  Take 606 until it intersects with county route 659.  Take 659 east.  Once you get on the Buffalo Ridge topo, drive for ¾ mile to an access road to the north east.  Go 100 feet down the access road and the site is to the south.

Take State Route 60 east until the intersection with county route 657 south.  Take 657 until the intersection with 622.  This intersection is a sharp turn to the southeast and turns quickly to the north.  Follow it until you reach a populated area 0.9 miles before Allen’s Creek.  Once you stop on 622 go north approximately 700 feet on a hillslope near Dry Branch Creek.

Take State Route 60 East until the intersection with county route 622 south.  Take this road until you reach the town of Allen’s Creek.  Before you cross the creek, you will see county route 768.  Take it for approximately ¼ of a mile.  Stop the car and climb up the nearly vertical hill until you reach an old logging road.  This road turns into a driveway about ¾ of a mile to 1 mile from where you pick it up.  There is a house and directly after the house about 50 feet east of the driveway in the woods is the site.
East of Rt 704 and Hughesville

intersection of 721 and 605
drive 1/4 mile NW
pull off onto access road on right (north)
walk down .25 miles to site 424
From intersection of 56 and 647 take 56 south across bridge and park at first house on right (West).  Site is 1/2 mile upstream of small creek.

Take 29 S to 60 E at Amherst.  Take 60 E 10+ miles until just before you reach the James River.  They'll be a road with a number in 800's to your right (I think 810).  Turn right here and site 702 is just on the other side of the railroad monitoring station (you'll see the towers over the tracks).  The site is about 30 ft behind and slightly to the right of those railroad towers.
Enter Issak Walton Park from Bus 15 in Leesburg on southside

From Charlottesville, take 64 East to 15 South and then take a right onto 631.  As 631 veers straight to the left, take the access road on the right.  The site will be on the right side of the access road about ½ mile down the road where it takes a sharp left.
Access via Rt600 from US15
properties.OlacNotes: DIABASE

properties.Directions: Site is in Bull Run Mountain Estates
Hike in from Rt629 north of Hopewell Gap
Park at Hopewell Gap and hike south along ridgeline

From Charlottesville, take 64 East to 15 South.   When in the town of Dillwyn, turn right onto 1017.  Sites 402 and 403 can be found less than ½ mile up the road.  From that point, walk North Northeast past the other gold mines until site 410 is reached.  It is about ¾ mile walk from the road.

This site is in the same cluster of slate mines as sites 101, 102, and 105. From Esmont take 715 N to Saint Ann's Parish, about 2 hundred yards from town. Park there andn take the access road across the street to the E. This takes you onto a tree farm. Follow the gravel road untill you see slate debris to the left (N). This is the beginning of site 105, which is a conglomeration the remnants of a rail path for transport, and many morphologies of slate debris: A dike, a gully  a stream system which runs through the dike (flowing towards you), and an old siltated dam/pond. Across this in and over the hill a bit to the NE is site 104.

From the intersection of 611 and 721, take 611 SW  for just under a mile, until you see a road that cuts back and drops down to the NE, turn there and follow the paved road about half a mile untill you reach a place where the power lines make a cut in the foliage in front of you, and the road turns left a bit. Park there. The site is to the SE, behind a basketball court. Walking this way you come to disturbed ground that has regrown the same age as surrounding forests. The site is extensive and spread out over the entire hillside, culminating almost at the woods end, a field with two ponds in the bottomland below.

From Charlottesville, take 29 South to 6 East.  Take a left on 627 and take a right onto a driveway after 1 mile.  Take the right at the end of the larger driveway to a smaller one.  Drive up to the house.  The map is misleading since it says that the site is located South-Southeast from the end, but it is really to the South-Southwest.
From Charlottesville, take 29 South to 60 East.  Take a left on an access road ¼ mile before reaching 626 on the left.  The sites are on the right side about ¾ mile up the access road.

From Charlottesville, take 29 South to 60 East.  Take a left on 626 and travel for about 6 or 7 miles.  Stop along side the road about ¼ mile before Buffalo station, and it will be about ¼ mile Southwest of the road

From Charlottesville, take 29 South to 60 East.  Take a right on 622 and turn right on 768 which travels along Allens Creek.  Find the road-side adit and walk straight up Buck Mountain to find the prospects.
From Charlottesville, take 29 South to 60 East.  Take a right onto 622 and veer left onto 656.  Less than ¼ mile on the left is a poorly kept access road.  Follow the road up the hill to the mine.

From Charlottesville, take 29 South to 60 East.  Take a right onto 622 and veer left onto 656.  Follow 656 into Gladstone and park.  Get out and walk along the railroad tracks past the water tank and first quarry on the right.  This marble quarry will be located there on the right.

From Charlottesville, take 29 South to 56 East.  Take a left on 626 and take another left on a small access road about 5/8 mile after passing a cemetery on the left.  The mines should be on the left just less than a mile down the access road and right before it intersects with another access road.

From Charlottesville, take 29 South to 460 East.  Take a left onto 608 and then another left onto 721.  Take a right onto 622 and a left on 624.  After a very sharp bend in the road, get out and walk straight Northeast past half a dozen shafts and adits to reach site 108.

From Charlottesville, take 29 South to 460 East.  Take a left onto 608 and then another left onto 721. Take a right onto 622 and a left on 624.  After a very sharp bend in the road, get out and walk straight Northeast past half a dozen shafts and adits to reach site 109.

From Charlottesville, take 29 South to 460 East.  Take a left onto 608 and then another left onto 721. Take a right onto 622 and a left on 624.  After a very sharp bend in the road, get out and walk straight Northeast until you reach the first two adits.  From there, walk straight East to reach site 116.
Site along Rt 733
On US15 at Mountain Gap
At Evergreen Mills on Rt 621
properties.OlacNotes: BASALT

properties.Directions: In Lake Anna State Park at the above coordinates.

intersection of 721 and 605
drive 1/4 mile NW
pull off onto access road on right (north)
walk down .25 miles to site 423
From intersection of 622 and 656 take 622 east for two miles.  Park on curve, site is ¼ mile north.
From intersection of 622 and 656 take 622 east for two miles.  Park on curve, site is ½  North of road.
on US15 Bypass in McDonalds parking lot
From Charlottesville, take 29 South and then take a right onto 653.  Take a left onto 652.  It is on the right side of the road after a sharp left turn and an immediate sharp bend to the right.

From Charlottesville, take 29 South and take a left onto 653.  Take a right onto 668 and travel about 1 ¼  miles down 668 to get to the site which will be on the left side of the road between 2 mountain peaks.

Take 60 N from the James River crossing at Caskie. About 2 miles later turn right onto Rt. 626 and folow it until you come to Four Forks,  and from there take 606 along the ridge above the James. Pass the no dumping sign where power lines split down the slope, proceed another hundred feet, park, and find a way to descend the slope to the bottom. Site is easily visible from the railroad tracks.
From Charlottesville, take 29 South to 60 East.  Take a left on 626 and it will be located on the right side about 2 ¾ miles down the road just before reaching Owens Creek.
Drive in along private road from Rt601 and Rt629, park and hike in.
along Rt 600 south of Rt 55
drive into residential area from Rt 676
Drive south on private road from Rt 601 and Rt629, then hike to site
Park @ Bull Run Mountains Natural Area in Beverly at north side of Thoroughfare Gap and hike in on Quarry Trail.
Rt 50 to Rt 742 and drive into commercial parking lot
Along Rt 50 in Chantilly
Off Rt 50 in residential area
off Coppermine Road east of Dulles
Take Bull Run Drive south of I66
park at Greenbrier Park off Rt645
properties.OlacNotes: Copper also present.

properties.Directions: Off Rt 658 at Union Mill Rd

From 15 South, you travel across the James River and take a right onto Rt. 652.  Follow Rt. 652 until you pass through Bridgeport.  Just on the opposite side of Bridgeport will be Site 206, on the right hand side of the road.  If you reach the rail, you have gone too far, it is 100yds towards Bridgeport.  Be careful acessing the site from the top, it is best to walk down to the railroad and back towards Bridgeport because of the high wall.
properties.OlacNotes: OLP to relook at site.

properties.Directions: From 29 South, take a left onto Highway 56 headed East.  After passing through Shipman, take a right onto Rt. 626.  Follow 626 along the river until you reach the town of Norwood.  Take a right onto Rt. 655 and follow it until you reach Old Farm Loop.  Take a right onto Old Farm Loop and park near the house.  Walk along the creek 500yds and the first site will be on the left, 30ft above the creek and it is the first of a long series of pits at the same elevation.

From Rt. 622, take a left onto Rt. 721 and cross over the James River.  Stay on 721 until you reach Rt. 671 and it will become a tertiary road.  Take a left onto Rt. 671 and stay to the left when the road splits.  Be cautious as it is a dirt road.  The Road will bend back to the right sharply and just after the bend on the left there will be Site 410 and 408 and 409 just below the shaft at 410.

From Rt. 622, take a left onto Rt. 721 and cross over the James River.  Stay on 721 until you reach Rt. 671 and it will become a tertiary road.  Take a left onto Rt. 671 and stay to the left when the road splits.  Be cautious as it is a dirt road.  The Road will bend back to the right sharply and just after the bend on the left there will be Site 410 and 408 and 409 just below the shaft at 410.
properties.OlacNotes: ESPECIALLY BAD SITE

properties.Directions: 29 South to Amherst; 60 East, then about a quarter of a mile south on 657.  There is a gravel driveway just before a bend in the road to the right.  The site was on the side of a gravel road about a quarter of a mile off of Rt. 657, approximately 75 yards from a trailer.

Take 29 South to 60 East, making a right on Rt. 600 (Riverville Road).  After about 5 miles, turn left onto 622.  At the top of a ridge, there were several homes and a good place to pull over onto the side of the road.  We walked southwest down the ridge towards the James River to follow the railroad tracks to the sites.
From 60 South, take a left onto Rt. 626.  Stay to the right when you come to the fork in the road and then a left onto Rt. 606.  Follow 606 for two miles and the site will be on your right.

29 South to 60 East in Amherst.  14.5 miles along 60 East (after crossing over the James River), turn right onto 605 for about 6 miles.  There was an access road off to the right where we pulled over and began our climb up to the top of the ridge.  At the top, we headed southwest towards 951

29 South to 56 East in Lovingston.  Take 56 to 626.  Make a left onto 626, making a right onto 602, which crosses over the James River.  Just over the bridge, make the first right into a cow pasture.  Follow the driveway around the first switchback and park.  Walk from the car west-northwest to the site, which will be down a bit of a slope.

29 South to Rt 739.  Turn left onto 739, then a left at the “T” with 657.  After 1 mile, make a left onto 654.  Stay on this past the sharp bend in the road and keep going past an air field to the right.  Then, make a left onto 655 and find a good place to pull off the road after about 3 miles.  Then walk southwest towards the sites.  This involves crossing Rucker Run.
Entrance to site on Rt 55 east of Rt 600
properties.OlacNotes: BASALT

properties.Directions: 29 S to Shipman, then 56 E.  Take 56 E until you reach 626, then take a left onto 626.  After about a mile you'll see route 743; take another left.  This road will wind up through some hill before ending at a stream.  Cross the stream and you'll see a gate and a house at the end of a field.  Walk through the field to the house and turn left to go over the hill.  You'll cross over this hill, go down into a drainage, then come up on another hill.  The site is on this hillside - total walking distance of about 500-600 ft.
From intersection of 722 and 56 head south on 56 for a mile and a half.  Park at gated access road on left (east).  Site is at very end of access road.

From 60 East, take a left onto Rt. 626.  Stay on 626 until you reach a Y in the road.  Stay to the right and take a left onto Rt. 607.  Follow 607 until it runs into the railroad.  Park at the rail road and walk South along the rail and the site is 100yds down and on the right of the railroad, 20yds into the woodline.

29 South to 56 East in Lovingston.  Take 56 to 626.  Make a left onto 626, then after 3 miles, making a left onto 604.  A little over a mile northwest on 604, we pulled over and walked southwest along the lower base of a ridge on the other side of Buckley Spring.
center of Leesburg, off 15 Bus
On Rt 28 and just north of Rt 625
Hike in of Rt 629
Hike in from Rt 629
From Charlottesville, take 29 South and then a right onto 56 West.  The site will be on the right side of the road at the corner of 56 West an 655.

From Esmont take 715 N a few hundred yards, and park at Saint Ann's Parish. Accross the street there is an access road through a tree farm that leads to a large abandoned slate mining operation. As you walk up the gravel access road you will come to a place where there is a lot of slate debris to your left. Follow this debris, which lines the old rail path along the edge of a bottom land and directly to an old dike and siltated dam. Site 102 is a large impounded quarry in the woods, and the stream in the valley take you within sight.

From Norwood Va, take 665 NW. A few hundred yards from the mouth of the Tye River there is an old loop driveway-road that has lost its bridge over a creek that flows SE. Park off the loop and follow the creek up stream through the valley. When the creek takes a turn for the right and the left bank of the steam widens out, find a way to be on the left W side. The site is in the woods on the edge of a groove or cut in the topography hidden by mountain laurels.

Same as site 601, but not as far. 56 E from Red Apple Orchard, about a mile and past BM 685. There is a new development for some kind of camp, and the acess road is unnamed but gated, and there is much regrading and clearing. Follow the access road SW to the end of the plateau, and then proceed NW over a small creek and over a hill, the site is at the edge of a clearing that looks in the direction of site 601.
Park at Hopewell Gap and hike in along ridge

From Charlottesville, take 29 South to 56 East.  Drive down past Red Apple Orchard.  It will be located on a hilltop on the left side of the road as the road makes a left bend ½ mile past Hebron Church.
Park at BullRunMountains Natural Area, on north side of Thoroughfare Gap at Beverley Mill and hike in on Quarry Trail for natural area.
on Rt 645 off US29

From Rt. 622, take a left onto Rt. 721 and cross over the James River.  Stay on 721 until you reach Rt. 671 and it will become a tertiary road.  Take a left onto Rt. 671 and stay to the left when the road splits.  Be cautious as it is a dirt road.  The Road will bend back to the right sharply and just after the bend on the left there will be Site 410 and 408 and 409 just below the shaft at 410.
From 60 South, take a left onto Rt. 626.  Stay to the right when you come to the fork in the road and then a left onto Rt. 606.  Follow 606 for two miles and the site will be on your right.

29 South to Rt 739.  Turn left onto 739, then a left at the “T” with 657.  After 1 mile, make a left onto 654.  Stay on this for about 5 miles then make a left onto an access road.  If you hit the sharp bend in the road and see an air field to the right, you’ve gone too far.  Take the acess road to a small clearing about a quarter of a mile in, park, and head north east until you run into the site.
south side of Rt601, east of Hopewell Gap

Turn north on route 626 from 29N in Five Forks. Travel on 626 approximately 3 miles, past several houses and a church on the left, until an intersection with a dirt road. Site's opening is on NE side of 626, approximately 50 ft N of intersection.

Directions: From the intersection of 605 and 610 on the Caledonia Quad, turn left onto 610 East (White Hall Rd.).  Follow 610 East to 651 South and after approximately one mile, pull off to the side of the road at an access road on the right (west) side.  Park at the end of the access road (was gated at the time of site observation) and walk along the access road.

2)Alternate Directons (which involve less walking): From the intersection of 605 and 610 on the Caledonia Quad, turn off onto an access road ¾ of a mile after the intersection.  The trail goes into the woods for 2 miles to the site.  The trail may be gated off about ¼ of a mile before the sites due to the fact that the land is owned by a hunt club.  If this is the case, park at the gate and continue walking to the site.  If this is not the case, drive until the bridge crosses the stream and walk approximately 1 mile (just slightly more than one mile) to the site.

From the intersetion of 15 and 671 on the Arvonia Quadrangle, drie 1.5 miles Northwest on 671.  Stop when reach the railroad tracks and park.  Follow the railroad tracks approximately 0.5 mi NNW, you will see the quarry on your left (west).

from the intersection of 15 and 22 on the Boswell's Tavern quadrangle, drive 0.5 miles south on 15 until you cross a small bridge.  Pull over and walk through the field, across the earthen impoundment, and around the edge of the lake to the 'end point' of the lake.  Total walk from the road is 0.75 miles

Take rt29 South for about 40 miles. Then turn left onto rt739 for about 9 minles. Then turn left on rt60 for about 3 miles past the intersection of rt622. After passing rt622 you should see about 5 houses on the right then 2 on the left. Park on this road just after you have paased these houses. You will start walking to the left side of the road. You will walk about 1.5 miles NE to the site via a trail.

Take rt29 South for about 40 miles. Then turn left onto rt739 for about 9 minles. Then turn left on rt60 for about 3 miles past the intersection of rt622. After passing rt622 you should see about 5 houses on the right then 2 on the left. Park on this road just after you have paased these houses. You will start walking to the left side of the road. You will walk about 1 mile NE to the site via a trail.

Take rt29 South for about 40 miles. Then turn left onto rt739 for about 9 minles. Then turn left on rt60 for about 3 miles past the intersection of rt622. After passing rt622 you should see about 5 houses on the right then 2 on the left. Park on this road just after you have paased these houses. You will start walking to the left side of the road. You will walk about 1.75 miles NE to the site via a trail.
DIRECTLY BEHIND HOME OF MIKE BROWN IN CURVE OF THE ROAD OFF ROUTE 622, OFF OF THE WOODS TOAD LEADING TO THE BIG HARRIS MINE
properties.OlacNotes: THE SITE APPEARS TO BE A TUNNEL OF UNNOWN EXTENT WITH SUBSIDENCE PRESENT FOR APPROX. 25'. THE SITE IS IN THE YARD OF A HOME WTIH A SMALL CHILD, AND POSES A SEVERE HAZARD DUE TO THE ENTRANCE BEING OPEN.  THE ENTRANCE WAS CLOSED WITH BOARDS AND LOGS TO PREVENT ENTRY.  A REPRESENTATIVE OF THE OTTER SOIL AND WATER CONSERVATION DISTRICT HAS INVESTIGATED THE SITE AS A STUMP DUMP CAVITY, BUT WHEN HE VIEWED IT IT DID NOT PRESENT AS ONE HE AHD SEEN BEFORE.  THE SITE HAS WHAT APPEARS TO BE CRIB SUPPORTS, BUT THAT IS QUESTIONABLE.  IT SIR ECOMMENDED THAT THE ENTRANCE BE EXCAVATED TO DETERMINE WHAT IT IS AND IF IT IS A TUNNEL, PROCEED TO CLOSE AS APPROPRIATE.

properties.Directions: From intersection of 15 and 22, follow 15 S appx .5 mi (if you reach a dirt road/driveway, you have gone too far). Park on 15 on right side of road, walk due W through cow field to impoundment.  Follow border of impoundment along S side until first major valley.  The site lies in that valley, appx. 10 yds. E of creek that feeds into impoundment.
properties.OlacNotes: Merged with DMM04803 on 2/28/2017, record by Wenger (UVA)

properties.Directions: From the intersection of state roads 605 and 606.  Drive south for two miles on 605 until the topography begins to become steep to the east.  From there walk east along the base of the hill, towards the James River, about 2000 feet, until the site is reached.
Drive 60 west to the intersection with state road 622.   Park one half mile west of the intersection.  From there, walk north about 500ft to the site.
Drive 60 west to the intersection with state road 622.   Park one half mile west of the intersection.  From there, walk north about 700ft to the site.

from the intersection of 659 and 609 on the quad, turn right (south) onto 659.  Drive approximately 1/10 of a mile south and pull over on the side of the road (is a peak in the road).  The road has recently been straightened.  There is a gated access road on the north side of 659.  Follow this road approximately 1/5 of a mile to 933.  You will cross 3 reclaimed sites (833, 834, 826) along the way.

Take 64 east for about 15 miles to rt 15 south toward Cumberland County for about 20 minutes, then make a left onto rt 610. Stay on rt 610 for about 1 mile until you get into Cumberland County. The when you will see a tank farm coming up on your right. Make the right before the tank farm onto rt 609. Take rt 609 for about 3 miles then makea right onto rt 608. Take 608 for about 1.5 miles. Then there should be an access road on the right side road. Take the access road for about 1 mile, to the end of the clear cut. Once past the clearcut, walk for about 1/2 mile, and then enter the forest to the right. The site should be about 1/4 mile in.

From intersection of 460 and 726, follow 726 N for appx, one mile. Site will be on the right (E) side of the road appx. 200 ft. before bridge for train tracks crosses the river on the other side of the road.  Site is directly off of 726.

From intersection of 460 and 726, follow 726 N appx. one mile, passing under RR bridge that crosses the James River. Immediately after the bridge, there will be a house on the right (E) side of the road. The site is appx. 300 ft. behind the house, S of the creek that runs into the James.
properties.OlacNotes: 2B 4C

properties.Directions: Take 64 E to rt15. Go North on Rt 15 toward Gordonsville. Take rt 15 N for 5 miles of when you will see a large cleared field on the left. This is where you park. Walk through the clear field for about 0.5 miles. Walk up on ridge at one end of lake and bear left to avoid livestock, following curvature of lake for about 0.5 miles. Then cut northwest through forest for about 0.25 miles until you see the lake again. Site is about 40ft before you reach the lake

from the intersection of 622 and 648 on the Kelly quad, drive north approximately 1.25 miles on 648 until you reach a dirt road cut for a new development, not too far beyond a natural spring with a pipe sticking out of it.

From intersection of 29 and 622, follow 622 E appx. 1.5 mi.  Turn right  (S) on 672.  Follow 672 S for appx. 1.5 mi.  Site is on the left of the road, right before a major valley on the left.  Site is located about 150 ft. NW of road at that point.
ENTRANCE ROAD 1/10 MILE FROM INTERSECTION 648 & 604.
From the intersection of state roads 648 and 613. Drive southwest 2000 feet and park on the right of the road.  From here, walk northwest 1000 feet until the site is found.
From intersection of 460 and 726, follow 726 E and stop at the county line. You can walk along Joshua creek appx. .25-.5 mi, site will be on the south side, up on the second hill  you come across.
From intersection of 460 and 726, follow 726 E until major bend in road. site is on the left side of the road at this bend, appx 150 ft. downhill from house.

From intersection of 460 and 726, follow 726 E until large bend in road. at this bend, road starts going uphill. sites are on the left side of the road at the top of this hill,  in the backyard of the house.
From intersection of 460 and 726, follow 726 E until large bend in road.  at bend, walk into woods heading NE and follow Chestnut Mtn. ridge appx .75 mi.

Take 29 south to Lynchburg, then take 460 E for about 10 miles. Then take 726 N for 1/2 mile. Then make a right onto 609. Take this for about 5 miles. Then make a left on 611. Stay on this road for about 2 miles. Park along this road where the land somewhat levels off. The site will be on the left side of the road.

Take 29 south to Lynchburg, then take 460 E for about 10 miles. Then take 726 N for 1/2 mile. Then make a right onto 609. Take this for about 5 miles. Then make a left on 611. Stay on this road for about 1.5 miles. Park along this road where the land somewhat levels off. The site will be on the left side of the road.

Take 29 S for about about 40 miles, then make a left on 677 for 5 miles and then take a left on 669 for 5 more miles. Then take a right on 663 for about 1/2 miles. Park on this road. This site will be on your left.
properties.OlacNotes: 6C

properties.Directions: Take 29 S for about about 40 miles, then make a left on 677 for 5 miles and then take a left on 669 for 5 more miles. Then take a right on 663 for about 4 miles then make a right onto 613. Follow 613 for 3 miles taking the left fork in the road when it arises. Park at the end of this road and walk for about a mile NE. The site will be on your right.

Take 29 south to Lynchburg, then take 460 E for about 10 miles. Then take 726 N for 1/2 mile. Then make a right onto 609. Take this for about 2 miles. Then make a right on 659. Stay on this road for about 1.5 miles. Park along this road where the land becomes somewhat level on your right and somewhat steep on your left. The site will be on the left side of the road.

From US Route 15 South.  At Fork Union go west on State Route 6.  Continue on State Route 6 until the intersection with State Route 640 South.  Take State Route 640 south until it ends at the railroad tracks.  Follow the railroad tracks to the southeast along the James River for approximately ¾ of a mile.  The site is to the north of the tracks.

From 29 South, go east on State Route 677.  At the intersection with State Route 622 go east on 622.  At the intersection with state route 663 go north on 663.  663 intersects has a y-intersection with state route 613, take the right fork which is 613.  About ½ mile from this intersection there are 2 roads to the north of 613.  One is to the northwest and the other is to the northeast.  Take the northeast one.  After about ½ mile on this road, it becomes a private driveway.  About ½ mile down the driveway and 1500 feet into the woods to the east is the site.

From US Route 29 South take US Route 460 east.  At the intersection with State Route 626, take 626 north.  Continue following State Route 626 until it crosses over Joshua Creek.
